GR-25 OF GR-26 RESERVATION FOR SAND DEPOSITS NORTH AND SOUTH OF ASKAR. s.f We thank you for your letter N0.C/L .6 dated 8th May, 194-5, and appreciate the wish of the Bahrein Government to prevent these areas from becoming marshland after the sand has been removed. The suggestion, however, that a strip of sand not less than fifty feet wide be left intact and outside the reserved area and that sand should only be removed to a depth of six inches is, we believe, hardly practical if the Company is to take sand from these areas. The top few inches of sand would in any case be useless to the Company for the making of concrete due to dust and other deleterous materials; also, the recovery of sand for a depth of a few inches would hardly con stitute an economical operation and the amount obtained would be ex tremely small compared with the Company's requirements. The Company 1 s intention was to excavate the site to(thqf 0^ depth of several feet, depending on the thickness of the sand deposit, and an examination of the contours of the area indicates that if this was done, flooding of the area, apart from the actual workings, would not result. It would appear that the most practical way of obtain ing sand from the proposed reservation would be to excavate as close to the sea shore as possible, leaving an area on completion which would be flooded at high tide, but restricted in extent to the actual ex cavation. An extensive survey of sand deposits on Bahrein has been conducted recently by the Company samples taken and tested from many locations. It has been found that in a great number of cases the sand is unsuitable for certain of the Company^ special building work because of its chemical composition or physical properties. Askar is the nearest location to the Refinery where sand in any quantity is found which is suitable for the Company^ purpose. physicalDescription.extent: The documents in the file are arranged in chronological order. There is an index at the end of the file (folios 25-26). The index is arranged chronologically and refers to documents within the file; it gives brief description of the correspondence with a reference number which refers back to that correspondence in the file.

The foliation is written in pencil, in the top right corner. The numbering begins on the cover, on number 1; then 2-4; 5A, 5B and 5C; 6-15; 16A and 16B; 17; 18A, 18B and 18C; and carries on until 27, which is the last number given on the back cover of the file.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Political Resident at Bushire, the Adviser to the Government of Bahrain, Charles Dalrymple Belgrave, and Bahrain Petroleum Company Limited (BAPCO) representatives on reservations for sand deposits near Askar.There are some maps within the file:'RESERVATION SOUTH OF ASKAR FOR SAND DEPOSITS' (f. 5B);'RESERVATION NORTH OF ASKAR FOR SAND DEPOSITS' (f. 5C);'A RESERVATION FOR NATIVE MUD DEPOSITS' (f. 16A);'A RESERVATION FOR SAND DEPOSITS NORTH OF JASAIRA' (f. 18B).There is an index at the end of the file (folios 25-26).
